With catatonia: This specifier can apply to an episode of mania
or depression if catatonic features are present during most of the
episode. See criteria for catatonia associated with a mental dis-
order in the chapter “Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psy-
chotic Disorders.”
With peripartum onset: This specifier can be applied to the cur-
rent or, if the full criteria are not currently met for a mood episode,
most recent episode of mania, hypomania, or major depression
in bipolar I or bipolar II disorder if onset of mood symptoms oc-
curs during pregnancy or in the 4 weeks following delivery.
Note: Mood episodes can have their onset either during preg-
nancy or postpartum. Although the estimates differ according
to the period of follow-up after delivery, between 3% and 6% of
women will experience the onset of a major depressive epi-
sode during pregnancy or in the weeks or months following
delivery. Fifty percent of “postpartum” major depressive epi-
sodes actually begin prior to delivery. Thus, these episodes
are referred to collectively as peripartum episodes. Women
